Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Legal Practices of State Neutrality in Educational Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The doctoral dissertation research project, which trains an anthropology graduate student in methods of scientifically rigorous and empirical data collection and analysis, aims to advance scientific understanding of the making of subject-citizens and state-subject relations in educational settings through a study of a the sociolegal concept of neutrality. The project would broadly disseminate its findings to organizations invested in improving educational policies. The project also broadens the participation of groups historically underrepresented in science, contributes the education of underrepresented groups, and builds capacity and scientific infrastructure through international cooperation in these scientific research communities.

Hafsa Oubou, under the supervision of Dr. Katherine Hoffman of Northwestern University, will explore the juridical concept of state neutrality in educational practice as it relates to the role of religion in schooling. This ethnographic research will explore how teachers of religion, respond to the politics of teaching or not teaching religion. Recent events have made the teaching of religion in public schools the subject of contentious debate, leading to redefining the concept of state neutrality and to re-imagining the place of religion in schools' curriculum. The investigator will examine how teachers negotiate the role of minorities' religion in education policies and will uncover how these teachers 1) navigate the discrimination towards religiosity, and 2) redefine the place of religion classes in public schools. During the fieldwork research, the researcher will conduct participant observation in education settings, semi-structured interviews, oral histories, and archival and media research. The project will advance anthropological theory related education, the subfield of political anthropology, and debates about secularism in the anthropology of religion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award examines how the intersection of education, religion, and race in public schools shapes religious and ethnic minorities in Belgium. After the 2016 attacks in Brussels, teachers of Islam and imams (prayer leaders) have become subjects of discrimination, accused for their alleged failure to teach the democratic values of le vivre ensemble, a popular French expression that means co-existence. The teaching of Islam in public schools in francophone Belgium suddenly became a point of contention rather than evidence of co-existence, leading to a growing suspicion towards teachers of Islam and a heated debate among political parties to remove courses in religion from public schools. Many teachers of Islam in public schools have recently engaged with the idea of le vivre ensemble as an Islamic value while navigating increasingly visible challenges: teaching Islam in a political climate that sees it as a threat to national security and responding to controversial education reforms that target courses of Islam. Using ethnographic methods from fieldwork in Belgium, this research explores how teachers of Islam translate and interact with the values of co-existence in an historical moment characterized by rising Islamophobia and extreme-right politics in Belgium. More broadly, this study looks at the controversies regarding teaching Islam in public education as a way to examine the question of Islam in Europe today.

Hafsa Oubou, an Anthropology PhD candidate at Northwestern University, conducted two years of fieldwork research in Brussels, as well as in the francophone region of Belgium. The researcher collected data through a variety of methods to have a better understanding of how teachers of Islam translate and engage with questions of neutrality and co-existence; the methods include participant observation, interviews, oral history, and archival and media research. In attempting to define what a neutral teaching of Islam might entail, the researcher uncovered some challenges for teachers and students. This research shows that the daily conversations and interactions in the classrooms demonstrate how teachers facilitate a discussion about Islam education while answering student questions that reflect the growing concerns of what it means to be Muslim today in Belgium. Many teachers of Islam find themselves not only at the forefront of a systematic racism rendering them central to the politics of accountability, but also face the burn-out of a heavily demanding job and the precarity of losing their job in the future. These concerns, challenges, and aspirations constitute the central objectives of this study.

These findings suggest that, in order to understand the controversies around the teaching or absence of teaching religion in public schools, particularly in courses on Islam in Europe, scholars and policymakers should take into consideration the history and context of public discourse about religious and ethnic minorities. Findings from this research will inform policymakers and scholars about how the intersection of religion, race, ethnicity, and migration plays a significant role in education policies. Findings from the research will be disseminated through academic publications and conference presentations.
